title: GPS Navigation and Coordinate Geometry
summary: How GPS systems use coordinate geometry and the distance formula to locate positions and plan routes anywhere on Earth.
content:
Case Study: GPS Navigation

Your smartphone's GPS receiver calculates your position by measuring the time delay of signals from at least four satellites. Each satellite defines a sphere of possible positions; the intersection of three spheres gives a unique location in 3D space — a direct application of coordinate geometry and the distance formula.

Key Mathematical Concepts

  • Distance Formula: d = √((x₂–x₁)² + (y₂–y₁)² + (z₂–z₁)²) in 3D.
  • Trilateration: Solving simultaneous equations of spheres to find the unique intersection point.
  • Map Projections: Converting spherical Earth coordinates (latitude/longitude) to a flat 2D map using geometric transformations.

Real-World Impact

From Ola and Uber rides to India's Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (NavIC), coordinate geometry underpins modern navigation. Understanding the mathematics demystifies how a device in your pocket knows exactly where you are on Earth.
